result.execSummary:
The defendant Tyler M. Mchugh was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Theft-Movable Property <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(a).
  • Criminal Damage to Property [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Tyler M. Mchugh in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  
9:00 a.m.  Court calls the case. 

State files Amended Information. 
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.
Atty Kryshak received a copy of the Amended Information and waives its reading. 

Defendant enters a plea of:  Counts 1 thru 3 - NO CONTEST

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty Counts 1 thru 3.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 4 is dismissed and read-in. 

State has complied with Victim Notification Statutes.
Atty Constable makes statements she has just found a written victim impact statement in the file.  
Atty Kryshak reviews the letter along with his client. 
Written statement is filed with the Court.
Atty Constable makes sentencing arguments to the Court.  Objects to Expungment.
Atty Kryshak makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

BY THE COURT:
Count 1 - After full payment of the restitution of $818.00 which is to be paid today thru the DA's office, 
Pay a fine of $300 plus costs including the DNA surcharge. 
Counts 2 & 3 - Pay costs including the DNA surcharge.  To be paid within 60 days. 

Court denies expungment for reasons stated on the record.
Plea/sentencing hearing on June 3, 2015 at 08:45 am.
Pre-trial conference on January 26, 2015 at 08:30 am.
Pre-trial conference on January 5, 2015 at 08:30 am.
Pre-trial conference on October 13, 2014 at 08:30 am.

Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.
  Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription. 
Do not possess any drug paraphernalia. 
Do not associate with any persons possessing or consuming illegal controlled substances.
  Submit to photographs and fingerprinting by the agency or to the law enforcement agency named in the criminal complaint.     
No contact with Mark or Kelly Kovatch or with the co-defendants.

State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 

NOT GUILTY Plea(s) entered.

Atty Cousins recommends a $10,000 signature bond with conditions as stated.

Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions Attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.

Defendant Tyler M. Mchugh in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. David R. Knaapen/Cass Cousins appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Attorney/Defendant received copy of criminal complaint.
Court informs defendant of charges and maximum penalties.
Attorney/Defendant waives reading of complaint.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for October 13, 2014 at 08:30 am.
